tn.text: Parallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_poetry]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
Possible meanings are 1) David wrote the psalm or 2) the psalm is about David or 3) the psalm is in the style of David's psalms.

tn.ref: I will give you thanks with my whole heart
tn.text: The heart here represents the emotions. Doing something sincerely or completely is spoken of as doing it with all one's heart. AT: "I will sincerely thank you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Possible meanings are 1) "in spite of the false idols that exist" or 2) "before the heavenly assembly," which means "in the knowledge of the angels in heaven."
Bowing down is a symbolic action that represents worship and giving honor. AT: "I will worship you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
This refers to what God has said. AT: "what you have said" or "your commands and promises" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: All the kings of the earth

tn.text: This expression stands for God himself. AT: "you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: Yahweh is high, yet he cares for the lowly
tn.text: Yahweh is above all creation in power, position, and authority. Yet his interest is in those who are humble in spirit, servants to all. This is a simple contrast.

tn.ref: the proud he knows from far off
tn.text: This expression probably means that God is not faithful to those who are proud. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Being in danger is spoken of as being in a physical place. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: you will reach out with your hand against the anger of my enemies
tn.text: God is spoken of as if he will strike the enemies with his hand. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Anger is spoken of as if it were an object instead of an emotion. AT: "my enemies, who are angry" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
God is spoken of as if he had physically used hands to create. AT: "you have created" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: the ones whom your hands have made
tn.text: This expression probably refers to the nation of Israel.
